META_PRIMARY_TOPICS: ai_advertising, pmax, asc, automated_bidding, creative_ai, black_box

META_SECTION_ID: ai_advertising_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4
META_TOPICS: purpose, ai_landscape, market_context
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

This document provides guidance on AI applications in advertising and media planning. As AI increasingly drives campaign optimization, creative generation, and targeting, media planners must understand capabilities, limitations, and oversight requirements.

Campaign Optimization:
- Automated bidding and budget allocation
- Audience expansion and targeting
- Placement optimization across inventory
- Real-time performance adjustments

Creative Generation:
- Text generation for ad copy
- Image generation for display and social
- Dynamic creative optimization (DCO)
- Automated creative testing

Advantages:
- Scale optimization beyond human capacity
- Real-time adjustment to performance signals
- Pattern recognition across large datasets

Challenges:
- Reduced transparency into decision-making
- Limited control over targeting and creative
- Difficulty measuring true incremental impact
- Platform incentives may not align with advertiser goals

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: black_box_campaigns
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5,6
META_TOPICS: pmax, asc, advantage_plus, amazon_dsp, black_box
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Overview:
- AI-powered campaign type consolidating ad sets and audiences
- Reduces manual targeting controls in favor of algorithmic optimization
- Includes Advantage Plus Shopping Campaigns and App Campaigns

How It Works:
- Advertiser provides creative assets and conversion objective
- Algorithm determines audience targeting dynamically
- Budget allocated automatically across placements

Performance Claims:
- Meta reports 12-20 percent improvement in cost per result
- Gains vary significantly by vertical and advertiser maturity

Planning Considerations:
- Limited audience exclusion capabilities
- Cannot fully separate prospecting from retargeting
- Creative quality becomes primary optimization lever
- Measurement relies on Meta conversion modeling

Best Practices:
- Provide diverse creative assets
- Use cost cap bidding for efficiency guardrails
- Monitor audience overlap with other campaigns
- Validate with incrementality testing

Overview:
- AI-powered cross-channel campaign across Search, Display, YouTube, Discover, Gmail, Maps
- Uses Asset Groups with creative elements optimized by AI
- Replaced Smart Shopping and Local campaigns

How It Works:
- Advertiser provides assets (images, videos, text) and conversion goals
- AI generates ad combinations from provided assets
- Algorithm optimizes across Google properties automatically

Performance Claims:
- Google reports 18 percent average improvement in conversions at similar CPA
- Results vary significantly by vertical
- Search cannibalization common concern

Planning Considerations:
- Very limited placement and audience transparency
- Difficult to attribute results to specific channels
- May cannibalize branded search traffic

Best Practices:
- Exclude brand keywords through negative keyword lists
- Monitor branded search impression share separately
- Use audience signals as hints rather than targeting
- Maintain parallel standard campaigns for comparison
- Implement incrementality testing before scaling

Overview:
- Programmatic buying with algorithmic optimization
- Leverages Amazon first-party purchase data
- Serves across Amazon owned-and-operated plus open web

Planning Considerations:
- Strong lower-funnel performance for retail
- Limited transparency into audience composition
- Consider retail media network alternatives
- Validate incrementality against organic Amazon sales

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: ai_validation_framework
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 6,8,9
META_TOPICS: validation, incrementality, testing, measurement
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

AI campaigns require additional validation due to reduced transparency:

INCREMENTALITY TESTING:
- Mandatory before scaling AI campaigns significantly
- Geographic holdouts preferred for statistical power
- Compare AI campaign lift to control group
- Typical finding: attributed results exceed incremental by 20-40 percent

CROSS-CHANNEL CANNIBALIZATION:
- Monitor brand search volume and efficiency
- Track organic conversion trends
- Watch for audience overlap indicators
- Measure new-to-brand customer rates

PERFORMANCE SUSTAINABILITY:
- Track efficiency trends over 90+ day windows
- Monitor for learning phase reversion
- Watch creative fatigue indicators
- Assess plateau patterns after initial gains

Before Scaling:
- Confirm incremental lift is positive and material
- Verify no significant cannibalization
- Establish efficiency baseline and guardrails

During Campaign:
- Weekly efficiency trend monitoring
- Monthly incrementality refresh if possible
- Quarterly comprehensive review

After Campaign:
- Document validated incremental contribution
- Update planning benchmarks
- Apply learnings to future AI campaign setup

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: human_oversight
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,8,9
META_TOPICS: oversight, brand_safety, creative_review, guardrails
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION, MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Brand Safety:
- Human review of AI-generated creative before launch
- Placement exclusion lists maintained and updated
- Regular audit of actual placements (where visible)

Budget Controls:
- Cost caps or ROAS targets as efficiency guardrails
- Daily budget limits to prevent runaway spend
- Alert thresholds for anomalous performance

Creative Quality:
- Human approval of all AI-generated text and images
- Brand guideline compliance verification
- Legal and regulatory review as needed

Daily: Budget pacing, major efficiency shifts
Weekly: Creative performance, placement audit
Monthly: Incrementality indicators, cannibalization check
Quarterly: Comprehensive validation and strategy review

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: ai_decision_guidance
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5,6
META_TOPICS: decision_framework, when_to_use, recommendations
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Strong Candidates:
- New advertisers without historical optimization baseline
- High volume conversion goals (1000+ per month)
- Diverse creative assets available
- Flexibility on audience composition
- Budget sufficient for learning phase (10K+ per month per platform)

Weak Candidates:
- Highly specific audience requirements
- Limited creative assets
- Need for granular channel attribution
- Strict audience exclusion requirements
- Low conversion volume (under 100 per month)

Scale UP when:
- Incrementality testing confirms positive lift
- Efficiency meets or exceeds targets
- No significant cannibalization detected
- Creative assets remain fresh

Scale DOWN or Pause when:
- Incrementality testing shows minimal lift
- Efficiency declining despite optimization
- Significant cannibalization of other channels
- Creative fatigue evident

For most advertisers, recommend hybrid approach:
- Maintain standard campaigns for transparency and control
- Test AI campaigns with 20-30 percent of budget
- Scale AI allocation based on validated performance
- Never fully abandon controllable campaigns

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: ai_fallbacks_references
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: fallback, cross_references
META_INTENT: WORKFLOW_HELP
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

IF incrementality data unavailable:
- Use industry benchmarks for typical AI vs standard lift
- Apply conservative discount (20-30 percent) to attributed results
- Flag need for validation before major scaling

IF creative assets limited:
- Recommend standard campaigns until assets developed
- AI campaigns require diverse assets for optimization
- Suggest creative development as prerequisite

IF channel transparency required:
- AI campaigns may not be appropriate
- Recommend standard campaigns with manual optimization
- Document trade-off between efficiency and visibility

- REF: MPA_Expert_Lens_Channel_Mix_v6_0.txt - Channel selection context
- REF: MPA_Expert_Lens_Measurement_Attribution_v6_0.txt - Incrementality testing
- REF: mpa_benchmark (Dataverse) - Performance benchmarks
- REF: RETAIL_MEDIA_NETWORKS_v6_0.txt - Amazon advertising specifics

META_DOCUMENT_TYPE: calculation_framework
META_PRIMARY_TOPICS: analytics, calculations, formulas, projections, forecasting, mmm
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7,8,9
META_INTENTS: BUDGET_PLANNING, MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE, BENCHMARK_LOOKUP
META_VERTICALS: ALL
META_LAST_UPDATED: 2026-01-16

META_SECTION_ID: analytics_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: purpose, scope, principles
META_INTENT: WORKFLOW_HELP
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

This document defines the complete analytical methodology for the Media Planning Agent. It specifies calculation formulas, forecasting models, validation rules, and measurement frameworks that the agent MUST use when building, optimizing, and evaluating media plans.

PRINCIPLE 1: SHOW YOUR WORK
The agent MUST show calculations and formulas when presenting projections.

PRINCIPLE 2: ACKNOWLEDGE UNCERTAINTY
All projections carry uncertainty. Communicate confidence levels and ranges, not single point estimates.

PRINCIPLE 3: DATA PROVENANCE
Every calculation MUST cite its data source. Internal benchmarks, user-provided data, and web research MUST be clearly distinguished.

PRINCIPLE 4: CONSERVATIVE DEFAULTS
When data is limited, default to conservative estimates.

PRINCIPLE 5: VALIDATE CONTINUOUSLY
Projections MUST be validated against benchmarks at every step.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: core_formulas
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7
META_TOPICS: formulas, cpm, cpc, cpa, roas, ctr, cvr, impressions, clicks, conversions
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING, MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

IMPRESSIONS FROM BUDGET:
Impressions = (Budget / CPM) times 1000

BUDGET FROM IMPRESSIONS:
Budget = (Impressions times CPM) / 1000

CPM FROM BUDGET AND IMPRESSIONS:
CPM = (Budget / Impressions) times 1000

CLICKS FROM IMPRESSIONS:
Clicks = Impressions times (CTR / 100)

CLICKS FROM BUDGET:
Clicks = Budget / CPC

CPC FROM BUDGET AND CLICKS:
CPC = Budget / Clicks

CTR CALCULATION:
CTR = (Clicks / Impressions) times 100

CONVERSIONS FROM CLICKS:
Conversions = Clicks times (CVR / 100)

CONVERSIONS FROM BUDGET:
Conversions = Budget / CPA

CPA CALCULATION:
CPA = Budget / Conversions

CVR CALCULATION:
CVR = (Conversions / Clicks) times 100

REVENUE CALCULATION:
Revenue = Conversions times AOV

ROAS CALCULATION:
ROAS = Revenue / Budget

CAC CALCULATION:
CAC = Budget / New_Customers

MER (MARKETING EFFICIENCY RATIO):
MER = Total_Revenue / Total_Marketing_Spend

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: reach_frequency_calculations
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7
META_TOPICS: reach, frequency, grps, trps, audience_reach
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING, AUDIENCE_TARGETING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

GRP (GROSS RATING POINTS):
GRP = Reach times Frequency
GRP = (Impressions / Total_Population) times 100

TRP (TARGET RATING POINTS):
TRP = Target_Reach times Frequency
TRP = (Impressions / Target_Population) times 100

REACH FROM GRPs (SAINSBURY METHOD):
Reach = 1 - (1 - (1/N))^GRP
Where N = Number of ad exposures needed to reach saturation

SIMPLIFIED REACH FORMULA:
Reach = GRP / (1 + (Frequency - 1) / N)

Effective frequency is the number of exposures needed for message impact.

RULE OF THUMB BY OBJECTIVE:
- Awareness: 3-5 exposures
- Consideration: 5-8 exposures
- Conversion: 7-10 exposures

EFFECTIVE REACH:
Effective_Reach = Reach at or above Effective_Frequency threshold

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: diminishing_returns
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7
META_TOPICS: diminishing_returns, saturation, response_curves, hill_function
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

The Hill function models response with saturation effect:

FORMULA:
Response = (Spend^alpha) / (K^alpha + Spend^alpha)

Where:
- Spend = Marketing investment
- alpha = Steepness of curve (typically 0.5 to 2)
- K = Half-saturation point (spend level at 50% response)

To estimate declining marginal returns:

FACTOR = 1 / (1 + (Current_Spend / Saturation_Point))

Apply factor to incremental spend projections.

Budget exceeds 1.5x optimal: Flag diminishing returns warning
Budget exceeds 2x optimal: Strong diminishing returns likely
Budget exceeds 3x optimal: Severe saturation, recommend reallocation

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: budget_optimization
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6
META_TOPICS: budget_allocation, optimization, marginal_roi, reallocation
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Marginal ROI measures return on next dollar spent:

mROI = (Incremental_Revenue - Incremental_Cost) / Incremental_Cost

Allocate budget where marginal returns are highest.
At optimal allocation, marginal ROI should be equal across channels.

If Channel A has higher mROI than Channel B:
- Shift budget from B to A
- Continue until mROI equalizes or constraints bind

Budget constraints:
- Minimum spend per channel (platform requirements)
- Maximum spend per channel (saturation limits)
- Total budget constraint
- Channel mix requirements

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: confidence_methodology
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7,8
META_TOPICS: confidence, uncertainty, ranges, data_quality
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

HIGH CONFIDENCE: 80-100 points
- Based on user-provided historical data with consistent performance
- Validated against actual results
- Range: plus or minus 10 percent

MEDIUM CONFIDENCE: 50-79 points
- Based on vertical benchmarks with some user validation
- Reasonable alignment with historical patterns
- Range: plus or minus 15-25 percent

LOW CONFIDENCE: 0-49 points
- Based on general industry benchmarks only
- No user-specific validation
- Range: plus or minus 25-40 percent

Data Source Quality: 0-30 points
- User historical data: 30 points
- Vertical benchmarks: 15 points
- General benchmarks: 5 points

Data Recency: 0-25 points
- Within 90 days: 25 points
- Within 180 days: 15 points
- Older than 180 days: 5 points

Data Consistency: 0-25 points
- Low variance: 25 points
- Medium variance: 15 points
- High variance: 5 points

Validation Status: 0-20 points
- Validated against actuals: 20 points
- Cross-validated: 10 points
- Not validated: 0 points

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: validation_thresholds
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7,8,9
META_TOPICS: validation, thresholds, warnings, benchmarks
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

CPM VALIDATION:
- Below vertical low: Flag as potentially unrealistic
- Above vertical high: Flag as expensive, investigate

CPC VALIDATION:
- Below 0.10: Likely display or low-intent traffic
- Above vertical high: May indicate competition or quality issues

CTR VALIDATION:
- Below 0.05%: Display normal, search concerning
- Above 10%: Validate targeting and creative

CVR VALIDATION:
- Below vertical median: Investigate landing page or targeting
- Above vertical best-in-class: Validate tracking

BUDGET PER CHANNEL:
- Below minimum threshold: Flag underfunded
- Flag channels below 5K per month

IMPLIED CPA VALIDATION:
- If Budget / Target_Conversions exceeds vertical high CPA by 50%: Flag unrealistic target
- If Budget / Target_Conversions below vertical low CPA: Flag optimistic

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: incrementality_formulas
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 8,9
META_TOPICS: incrementality, lift, control_group, statistical_significance
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
Lift = (Test_Conversions - Control_Conversions) / Control_Conversions times 100

Incremental_Conversions = Total_Attributed - (Baseline times Audience_Size)

Where Baseline = Control group conversion rate

Incrementality_Rate = Incremental_Conversions / Attributed_Conversions

Typical rates by channel:
- Brand search: 20-40%
- Non-brand search: 50-70%
- Retargeting: 30-50%
- Prospecting social: 40-60%
- CTV/Video: 60-80%

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: ltv_cohort_calculations
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,8
META_TOPICS: ltv, lifetime_value, cohort_analysis, retention
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING, MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: MEDIUM
LTV = Average_Order_Value times Purchase_Frequency times Customer_Lifespan
LTV = (AOV times Margin times Frequency times Lifespan) - Acquisition_Cost
Month_N_Retention = Customers_Active_Month_N / Customers_Acquired_Month_0

- Below 1.0: Losing money on acquisition
- 1.0-2.0: Marginal, may not cover overhead
- 2.0-3.0: Healthy for most businesses
- Above 3.0: Strong unit economics, potential to invest more

================================================================================

================================================================================

VERSION: 6.0

META_DOCUMENT_TYPE: expert_guidance
META_PRIMARY_TOPICS: brand_marketing, performance_marketing, funnel_balance, demand_generation
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 1,4,5
META_INTENTS: CHANNEL_SELECTION, BUDGET_PLANNING
META_VERTICALS: ALL

META_SECTION_ID: brand_performance_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 1,4
META_TOPICS: purpose, efficiency_paradox, brand_building, demand_generation
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

This document provides a framework for balancing brand building and performance marketing investments. Sustainable marketing effectiveness requires both demand generation through brand building and demand harvesting through performance marketing.

Performance marketing appears more measurable and efficient but creates hidden dependency:
- Performance channels harvest demand created elsewhere
- Brand advertising generates the demand pool that performance draws from
- Over-investment in performance depletes future demand
- Under-investment in brand reduces performance channel efficiency over time

1.3 LONG AND SHORT OF MARKETING (Binet and Field Research)

Research findings:
- 60 percent brand building and 40 percent activation recommended for most categories
- Brand effects build slowly but create lasting mental availability
- Performance effects work quickly but decay rapidly
- Brands with higher awareness achieve 2.86x higher conversion rates

Brand Building Creates Mental Availability:
- Brand comes to mind when purchase need arises
- Built through reach, frequency, and distinctive assets
- Measured through awareness, consideration, brand equity

Performance Marketing Ensures Physical Availability:
- Brand is present and easy to purchase when ready to buy
- Requires presence at point of decision
- Measured through direct response and conversion

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: funnel_investment
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5
META_TOPICS: funnel, upper_funnel, mid_funnel, lower_funnel, allocation
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION, BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Objective: Build mental availability with target audience
Channels: Television, CTV, video, audio, out-of-home, broad reach digital
Metrics: Reach, frequency, brand awareness, brand recall
Timeline: Effects accumulate over months to years
Typical allocation: 30-40 percent of budget

Objective: Move from awareness to active consideration
Channels: Content marketing, social, influencer, educational content
Metrics: Engagement, consideration, brand preference, search volume
Timeline: Effects develop over weeks to months
Typical allocation: 20-30 percent of budget

Objective: Capture demand at point of purchase decision
Channels: Search, retargeting, retail media, direct response
Metrics: Conversions, ROAS, CPA, sales
Timeline: Effects immediate to days
Typical allocation: 30-40 percent of budget

Demand Generation vs Demand Capture:
- Upper and mid funnel generate demand
- Lower funnel captures existing demand
- Performance channels cannot create demand, only harvest it

Funnel Fill Rate:
- Monitor ratio of upper funnel activity to lower funnel conversions
- Declining fill rate indicates brand investment shortage
- Rising CPAs without volume increases suggests demand pool depletion

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: allocation_by_maturity
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5
META_TOPICS: allocation, business_maturity, new_brand, growth_brand, mature_brand
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Typical allocation:
- Upper funnel: 50-60 percent
- Mid funnel: 20-25 percent
- Lower funnel: 20-25 percent

Rationale:
- Must build awareness before harvesting
- Limited existing demand to capture
- Brand building investment creates future efficiency

Typical allocation:
- Upper funnel: 35-45 percent
- Mid funnel: 20-30 percent
- Lower funnel: 30-40 percent

Rationale:
- Awareness established, consideration building
- Balanced investment across funnel
- Performance channels becoming efficient

Typical allocation:
- Upper funnel: 25-35 percent
- Mid funnel: 15-25 percent
- Lower funnel: 40-50 percent

Rationale:
- Strong existing awareness to maintain
- Large consideration set to harvest
- Efficiency optimization prioritized
- Caution: Reducing brand too much depletes demand over time

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: brand_measurement
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 8,9
META_TOPICS: brand_metrics, awareness, consideration, equity, measurement
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Awareness Metrics:
- Unaided awareness: Brand comes to mind without prompting
- Aided awareness: Brand recognized when prompted
- Top-of-mind awareness: First brand mentioned in category

Consideration Metrics:
- Consideration set inclusion: Brand among options being evaluated
- Brand preference: Brand favored over alternatives
- Purchase intent: Stated likelihood to purchase

Equity Metrics:
- Brand health index: Composite of awareness, consideration, sentiment
- Price premium: Ability to command higher prices than competitors
- Share of voice: Brand visibility relative to competitors

Leading indicators of brand health affecting performance:
- Branded search volume trends
- Direct traffic trends
- Organic social mentions
- Category conversion rate trends

When brand metrics decline, performance efficiency typically follows within 3-6 months.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: brand_diagnostics
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5,9
META_TOPICS: diagnostics, brand_health, performance_efficiency, warning_signs
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION, BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Warning signals:
- Rising performance CPAs without market changes
- Declining branded search volume
- Increasing cost to acquire new customers
- Shrinking consideration set in surveys
- Declining conversion rates on prospecting

Typical implications:
- Demand pool is being depleted
- Competitors gaining mental availability
- Need to rebalance toward upper funnel

Warning signals:
- Strong awareness but weak conversion
- High consideration but losing at point of purchase
- Competitors winning at decision point
- Poor share of voice in purchase channels

Typical implications:
- Demand exists but is not being captured
- Need presence at point of decision
- Balance toward lower funnel conversion

Healthy signals:
- Stable or improving branded search volume
- Consistent new customer acquisition costs
- Growing market share
- Strong conversion rates on prospecting
- Sustainable efficiency across funnel

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: brand_planning_recommendations
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5
META_TOPICS: recommendations, allocation_guidance, integration
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Recommend increasing upper funnel when:
- Performance CPAs rising without market explanation
- Branded search declining
- New customer acquisition becoming harder
- Awareness metrics declining
- Competitor brand investment increasing
sectionTitle: 6.1 WHEN TO RECOMMEND MORE BRAND INVESTMENT

content:
Recommend increasing lower funnel when:
- Strong awareness but poor conversion
- High consideration but losing at purchase
- Demand exists but capture is weak
- Short-term revenue goals critical
sectionTitle: 6.2 WHEN TO RECOMMEND MORE PERFORMANCE INVESTMENT

content:
- Maintain minimum 20-30 percent upper funnel for all but most mature brands
- Track brand metrics alongside performance metrics
- Use branded search as proxy for brand health
- Build measurement system that values demand generation
- Avoid optimizing to last-click at expense of demand creation

META_SECTION_ID: confidence_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 6,9
META_TOPICS: purpose, core_principle
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

This framework defines methodology for assigning and communicating confidence levels for all projections. Every forecast MUST include a confidence level indicator to ensure users understand projection reliability.

The agent MUST always communicate uncertainty honestly. Overstating confidence erodes trust. Understating confidence creates unnecessary concern. The goal is calibrated accuracy where stated confidence ranges match actual outcome distributions.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: confidence_definitions
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 6,9
META_TOPICS: high_confidence, medium_confidence, low_confidence, ranges
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Range: Plus or minus 5-10 percent

Characteristics:
- Based on platform-reported data or verified historical performance
- Calculations use known, stable inputs (contracted CPMs, guaranteed rates)
- Market conditions are stable and predictable
- Short forecast horizon (days to weeks)

When to Assign:
- Impressions from confirmed CPM and budget
- Reach from platform-provided audience size
- CPM projections based on contracted rates

Range: Plus or minus 15-20 percent

Characteristics:
- Based on industry benchmarks or similar campaign data
- Calculations include assumptions about engagement rates
- Market conditions are relatively stable
- Medium forecast horizon (weeks to months)

When to Assign:
- Click projections using benchmark CTRs
- Conversion projections with historical CVR data
- Efficiency metrics with reasonable benchmark basis

Range: Plus or minus 25-35 percent or higher

Characteristics:
- Based on general industry data or limited benchmarks
- Significant assumptions required
- Market conditions uncertain or volatile
- Long forecast horizon or new market entry

When to Assign:
- Revenue projections without historical data
- New channel performance estimates
- Long-range (3+ month) forecasts
- Novel audience or creative approach

META_SECTION_ID: data_input_scoring
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 6
META_TOPICS: data_quality, input_scoring, reliability
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Tier 1 - Highest Reliability:
- Client's verified historical data (same brand, same market)
- Platform-reported actuals from recent campaigns
- Contracted rates and guarantees

Tier 2 - High Reliability:
- Client's related historical data (similar products/markets)
- Category benchmarks from verified sources
- Platform planning estimates

Tier 3 - Medium Reliability:
- Industry benchmarks from reputable sources
- Analogous brand performance data
- Multi-source averaged benchmarks

Tier 4 - Lower Reliability:
- General category averages
- Extrapolated or modeled estimates
- Single-source benchmarks

Base confidence starts at MEDIUM.
Adjust based on data inputs:
- All Tier 1 inputs: Upgrade to HIGH
- Mix of Tier 1/2: Stay at MEDIUM
- Heavy Tier 3/4 reliance: Downgrade to LOW
- Missing critical inputs: Downgrade to LOW

META_SECTION_ID: communication_standards
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 9,10
META_TOPICS: display_format, ranges, communication
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Always present projections with:
- Point estimate (most likely outcome)
- Confidence level label (HIGH/MEDIUM/LOW)
- Range (lower bound - upper bound)

Example Format:
Projected Conversions: 50,000 (MEDIUM CONFIDENCE)
Range: 40,000 - 60,000

HIGH: Point estimate  0.90 to 1.10
MEDIUM: Point estimate  0.80 to 1.20
LOW: Point estimate  0.65 to 1.35

For critical decisions, present three scenarios:
- Conservative (lower bound)
- Base (point estimate)
- Optimistic (upper bound)

META_INTENT: GENERAL

This framework defines data source categories, trust hierarchy, and conflict resolution rules. The agent operates with data from multiple sources and must transparently attribute all values.

All data has a source. The agent MUST track and communicate where each piece of information originates. When sources conflict, the trust hierarchy determines which value to use.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: provenance_categories
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: category_1, category_2, category_3, category_4, source_types
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Trust Level: HIGHEST (for current session)

Characteristics:
- Information provided by user during current session
- Overrides all other sources for current session
- Stored in session context, not propagated to other users
- Client-specific targets, actual performance data, constraints

Examples:
- "Our CAC target is $65"
- "We are seeing $22 CPMs on Meta"
- "Total budget is $500K"
- Historical data from uploaded files

Agent Behavior:
- Accept immediately, use instead of other sources
- Note when user data differs significantly from benchmarks
- Remind user these are session-specific

Trust Level: HIGH

Characteristics:
- SharePoint-hosted KB documents and Dataverse tables
- Pre-validated benchmarks, updated quarterly
- Version-controlled and auditable
- Available to all users

Examples:
- mpa_benchmark (Dataverse) - Performance benchmarks
- mpa_kpi (Dataverse) - KPI definitions
- mpa_channel (Dataverse) - Channel characteristics
- Expert Lens documents - Diagnostic guidance

Agent Behavior:
- Use as default when user provides no override
- Cite as source when presenting benchmarks
- Cross-reference with web research when available

Trust Level: MEDIUM-HIGH

Characteristics:
- Real-time search during session
- Current but requires validation
- May conflict with KB (note discrepancy)

Examples:
- Census population data
- Current platform feature updates
- Recent industry reports
- Taxonomy code lookups

Agent Behavior:
- Use when KB is insufficient or outdated
- Cross-validate with multiple sources when possible
- Note recency and source in citation
- Flag when contradicting KB data

Trust Level: MEDIUM

Characteristics:
- Calculations and inferences by agent
- Based on Category 1-3 inputs
- Transparent methodology required

Examples:
- Interpolated benchmarks for uncovered verticals
- Projected outcomes from calculations
- Synthesized recommendations

Agent Behavior:
- Show calculation methodology
- State assumptions explicitly
- Acknowledge lower confidence for derived values

sectionTitle: SECTION 3: TRUST HIERARCHY AND CONFLICT RESOLUTION

content: 1. User Provided (Category 1) - Always highest for current session

3. Web Research (Category 3) - Supplements and validates
4. Agent Reasoning (Category 4) - When no other source available

User vs KB:
- User wins for current session
- Note if user data contradicts benchmarks significantly
- Do not challenge unless discrepancy is extreme

KB vs Web:
- KB wins for benchmarks unless KB explicitly outdated
- Web wins for current-state information (census, features)
- Note discrepancy for user awareness

Multiple Web Sources:
- Prefer authoritative sources (census.gov, platform docs)
- Average when multiple credible sources differ slightly
- Flag significant disagreement

Always include source attribution:
- Category 1: "Based on your provided data..."
- Category 2: "According to MPA benchmarks..."
- Category 3: "Per [source name]..."
- Category 4: "Calculated from..."

META_SECTION_ID: first_party_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 2,3
META_TOPICS: purpose, first_party_data, privacy_landscape
META_INTENT: AUDIENCE_TARGETING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

This document provides guidance on first-party data strategy for media planning. First-party data has become the foundation of effective marketing due to privacy regulations, consumer expectations, and platform signal loss.

Information collected directly from customers and prospects through owned touchpoints with consent:
- Website and app interactions
- Purchase and transaction history
- Customer account information
- Email and communication engagement
- Loyalty program participation
- Customer service interactions

Privacy Landscape Context:
- Third-party cookies blocked in Safari/Firefox (~21% of traffic)
- Regulatory requirements (GDPR, CCPA) restrict third-party data
- Consumer privacy expectations continue rising
- Platform signal loss from app tracking transparency

Marketing Effectiveness:
- Deterministic matching to known customers
- Higher accuracy than modeled or probabilistic data
- Better personalization drives improved outcomes
- Foundation for customer lifetime value optimization

First-Party: Collected directly, highest accuracy, requires consent
Zero-Party: Explicitly provided preferences, highest trust indicator
Second-Party: Partner's first-party data shared directly
Third-Party: Aggregated from providers, declining availability

META_SECTION_ID: data_activation
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 2,3,4
META_TOPICS: activation, lookalikes, suppression, retargeting
META_INTENT: AUDIENCE_TARGETING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

High-Value Lookalikes:
- Seed with top 10-20% customers by LTV
- Typically 40-60% better CAC than prospecting
- Update seed audiences quarterly minimum

Broad Lookalikes:
- Seed with all customers or converters
- Good balance of efficiency and scale
- Refresh monthly to capture recent patterns

Customer Suppression:
- Exclude existing customers from acquisition campaigns
- Update suppression lists weekly minimum
- Monitor new-to-brand rate as quality check

Recent Purchaser Suppression:
- Exclude recent purchasers from retargeting
- Window depends on purchase cycle (30-90 days typical)
- Prevents wasted spend on already-converted

Site Visitor Retargeting:
- 7-day visitors: highest intent, smaller pool
- 30-day visitors: balance of intent and scale
- 90-day visitors: broader reach, lower intent

Cart Abandoners:
- Highest intent retargeting segment
- Aggressive frequency acceptable (5-10/week)
- Time-decay messaging effective

Onboarding Sequences:
- New customer activation focus
- First 30 days critical for retention
- Cross-sell and education content

Win-Back Campaigns:
- Lapsed customer reactivation
- 90-180 day inactivity trigger typical
- Test offers and messaging

META_SECTION_ID: gap_detection_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: purpose, scope, principles
META_INTENT: WORKFLOW_HELP
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

This playbook defines the complete methodology for detecting gaps between projected outcomes and user targets, and for presenting structured options to close those gaps. The Media Planning Agent MUST use this playbook whenever projections fall short of stated objectives.

Gap detection and resolution is a core value-add of the agent. Users depend on the agent to:
- Identify when projections will not meet targets
- Quantify the gap precisely
- Present actionable options to close the gap
- Calculate the impact of each option
- Support unlimited iteration until user is satisfied
- Never rush to completion when gaps exist

This playbook applies to all gap scenarios including:
- PLANNING MODE: When initial projections miss targets
- IN-FLIGHT MODE: When actual performance trails planned performance
- POST-MORTEM MODE: When analyzing gaps between plan and actual for learnings

Gap detection covers all measurable KPIs:
- Conversion gaps (conversions, leads, signups below target)
- Revenue gaps (revenue, ROAS below target)
- Efficiency gaps (CAC, CPA above target)
- Delivery gaps (impressions, reach below target)
- Engagement gaps (clicks, CTR below target)

PRINCIPLE 1: PROACTIVE DETECTION
The agent MUST proactively identify gaps without waiting for user to notice. If projections miss targets by more than 10 percent, the agent MUST flag the gap.

PRINCIPLE 2: QUANTIFIED OPTIONS
Every option MUST include specific calculations showing exactly how it closes the gap. Vague recommendations are not acceptable.

PRINCIPLE 3: UNLIMITED ITERATION
The user can iterate as many times as needed. The agent MUST never rush to completion or suggest settling for suboptimal outcomes.

PRINCIPLE 4: NO JUDGMENT
The agent presents options without judgment. If user chooses to increase budget, adjust goals, or combine approaches, all are equally valid paths forward.

PRINCIPLE 5: TRANSPARENT TRADE-OFFS
Every option has trade-offs. The agent MUST clearly articulate pros and cons for each option.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: gap_calculation_methodology
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,9
META_TOPICS: gap_calculation, quantification, root_cause, formulas
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

The agent MUST trigger gap detection when:
- Projected outcome is more than 10 percent below target
- Projected cost metric is more than 10 percent above target
- User explicitly asks about hitting targets
- In-flight actual is more than 15 percent behind plan

FORMULA: Gap Percentage
Gap Percent = ((Target - Projection) / Target) times 100

The agent MUST quantify the gap in multiple ways:

ABSOLUTE GAP: The raw number difference between target and projection
PERCENTAGE GAP: The percentage shortfall from target
DOLLAR IMPACT: The revenue or cost impact of the gap
EFFORT TO CLOSE: What improvement is needed to close the gap

Before presenting options, identify the root cause:

BUDGET-DRIVEN GAP:
- Budget insufficient for target at current efficiency rates
- Symptom: All metrics proportionally short
- Solution focus: Increase budget or reduce target

EFFICIENCY-DRIVEN GAP:
- Budget adequate but efficiency (CTR, CVR) below benchmark
- Symptom: Impressions on track but conversions short
- Solution focus: Improve rates or adjust expectations

CHANNEL-DRIVEN GAP:
- Channel mix not optimal for objectives
- Symptom: Some channels overperforming, others underperforming
- Solution focus: Rebalance channel allocation

MARKET-DRIVEN GAP:
- External factors affecting performance
- Symptom: Benchmarks not holding in current conditions
- Solution focus: Adjust expectations or timing

The agent MUST communicate gaps using this format:

GAP DETECTED: Projection of [X] falls short of [target] by [Y] percent.

At current projections:
- You will achieve: [projection]
- Your target is: [target]
- Gap to close: [absolute gap] ([percentage] percent)
- Impact: [dollar or business impact]

Root cause assessment: [budget/efficiency/channel/market]

META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

When a gap is detected, the agent presents up to 6 options to close it. Not all options apply to every situation. The agent selects applicable options based on the gap type and user constraints.

THE 6 OPTIONS:

4. CHANGE CHANNEL MIX - Reallocate to more efficient channels
5. ADJUST GOAL - Revise target to match realistic projection

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
OPTION 1: INCREASE BUDGET
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

META_SECTION_ID: gap_option_increase_budget
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6
META_TOPICS: budget_increase, gap_closure, investment
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 2

WHEN TO PRESENT THIS OPTION:
- Gap is budget-driven (efficiency rates are reasonable)
- User has not indicated budget is fixed
- Additional investment is feasible

CALCULATION METHOD:

Current state:
- Budget: [current budget]
- Projected conversions: [current projection]
- Target conversions: [target]
- Gap: [gap amount]

To close gap through budget:
- Additional conversions needed: [gap]
- Current CPA: [budget / projected conversions]
- Additional budget needed: [gap times CPA]
- New total budget: [current + additional]
- Percentage increase: [additional / current times 100]

PRESENTATION FORMAT:

Option 1: Increase Budget

To achieve [target] conversions:
- Additional budget needed: [amount]
- New total budget: [amount] (up [X] percent from [current])
- Expected conversions: [target]
- Resulting CPA: [CPA] (unchanged)

Trade-offs:
- Pro: Maintains efficiency targets
- Pro: Straightforward to implement
- Con: Requires incremental investment
- Con: May face diminishing returns at scale

DIMINISHING RETURNS WARNING:
If budget increase exceeds 30 percent, warn user: Significant budget increases often see efficiency decline as campaigns exhaust high-intent audiences. Consider combining with efficiency improvements.

META_SECTION_ID: gap_option_adjust_goal
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 3,5,6
META_TOPICS: goal_adjustment, target_revision, expectation_setting
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

WHEN TO PRESENT THIS OPTION:
- Gap cannot be closed through options 1-4
- User indicates budget is fixed
- Market conditions make original goal unrealistic

CALCULATION METHOD:

If original target cannot be achieved:
- Calculate achievable target at current budget and benchmarks
- Present realistic expectation
- Quantify gap between original and achievable

PRESENTATION FORMAT:

Option 5: Revise Target

Based on [budget] and current benchmarks:
- Achievable conversions: [realistic projection]
- Original target: [original target]
- Recommended revision: Adjust target to [realistic]

Context:
- This represents [X] percent of original goal
- Current benchmarks suggest this is realistic given budget
- [Any market factors affecting performance]

Trade-offs:
- Pro: Sets achievable expectations
- Pro: Avoids overpromising
- Con: Does not hit original objective
- Con: May require stakeholder alignment

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
OPTION 6: COMBINE APPROACHES
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

META_SECTION_ID: gap_option_combine_approaches
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7
META_TOPICS: combined_options, hybrid_approach, multiple_levers
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

----------

META_SECTION_ID: gap_option_combine_approaches
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7
META_TOPICS: combined_options, hybrid_approach, multiple_levers
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

WHEN TO PRESENT THIS OPTION:
- Gap is too large for any single option
- User wants to balance risk across multiple levers
- Some options are partially applicable

CALCULATION METHOD:

Combine partial contributions from multiple options:
- Partial budget increase: [X] additional budget yields [Y] conversions
- Partial CVR improvement: [A] percent improvement yields [B] conversions
- Partial channel shift: Reallocation yields [C] conversions
- Total improvement: [Y + B + C]

PRESENTATION FORMAT:

Option 6: Combined Approach

To close the [gap] conversion gap:

Component 1 - Modest budget increase:
- Add [amount] ([X] percent increase)
- Yields: [Y] additional conversions

Component 2 - CVR optimization:
- Improve CVR by [Z] percent (from [current] to [target])
- Yields: [B] additional conversions

Component 3 - Channel reallocation:
- Shift [amount] from [Channel B] to [Channel A]
- Yields: [C] additional conversions

Combined result:
- Total additional conversions: [Y + B + C]
- Gap closure: [percentage] percent
- Remaining gap: [if any]

Trade-offs:
- Pro: Distributes risk across multiple levers
- Pro: More achievable than single large change
- Con: More complex to execute
- Con: Harder to attribute results

META_SECTION_ID: gap_iteration_guidance
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7,8
META_TOPICS: iteration, refinement, user_feedback, scenario_comparison
META_INTENT: WORKFLOW_HELP
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

The agent MUST support unlimited iteration. Users may:
- Ask to see different scenarios
- Combine options differently
- Add constraints mid-process
- Change priorities
- Request additional detail

The agent NEVER:
- Suggests settling for suboptimal outcomes
- Rushes to close the conversation
- Limits the number of iterations
- Shows impatience with continued exploration

Continue iterating when user says:
- What if we...
- Can you show me...
- Let me think about this differently
- What about combining...
- Is there another way...

When presenting multiple scenarios, use consistent format:

SCENARIO COMPARISON:

| Metric | Current | Option A | Option B | Option C |
|--------|---------|----------|----------|----------|
| Budget | [X] | [X+A] | [X] | [X+C] |
| Conversions | [Y] | [Y+A] | [Y+B] | [Y+C] |
| CPA | [Z] | [Z'] | [Z''] | [Z'''] |
| Gap Closure | 0% | [A%] | [B%] | [C%] |

META_SECTION_ID: gap_goal_adjustment_guidance
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 3,5,6
META_TOPICS: goal_adjustment, realistic_targets, expectation_management
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
sectionTitle: SECTION 5: WHEN TO RECOMMEND GOAL ADJUSTMENT

content:
Recommend goal adjustment when:
- Gap exceeds 40 percent and budget is fixed
- Required efficiency improvements exceed best-in-class benchmarks
- Market conditions have materially changed
- User has exhausted willingness to explore other options

Never frame goal adjustment as failure. Instead:

WRONG: Your goal is unrealistic. You should lower your expectations.

RIGHT: Based on current benchmarks and your budget constraints, a target of [X] would be achievable with high confidence. This represents [Y] percent of your original goal and would position the campaign for success within available resources.

Sometimes partial adjustment combined with optimization works:

Example:
- Original target: 10,000 conversions
- Achievable at current budget: 7,500 conversions
- With optimization: 8,500 conversions
- Recommended: Adjust target to 8,500 with optimization plan

META_SECTION_ID: gap_dialogue_examples
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6,7
META_TOPICS: examples, dialogue, conversation_patterns
META_INTENT: WORKFLOW_HELP
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 2

User: We have $500K budget and need 5,000 conversions.

Agent: Based on your vertical benchmarks, $500K would generate approximately 3,800 conversions at current efficiency rates.

GAP DETECTED: Projection of 3,800 falls short of 5,000 by 24 percent.

Gap to close: 1,200 conversions

OPTIONS TO CLOSE GAP:

Option 1: Increase Budget
- Additional budget needed: $158K
- New total: $658K (32% increase)
- Expected conversions: 5,000

Option 2: Improve Conversion Rate
- Current projected CVR: 2.5%
- Required CVR: 3.3%
- Improvement needed: 32% (challenging but possible)

Option 3: Combined Approach
- Add $80K budget (+16%)
- Improve CVR by 15% (2.5% to 2.9%)
- Combined result: ~5,000 conversions

Which option would you like to explore further?

User: We're getting plenty of traffic but conversions are short.

Agent: Let me analyze the efficiency gap.

Current state:
- Clicks: 150,000
- Conversions: 2,250
- CVR: 1.5%
- Target conversions: 3,500

GAP DETECTED: Current CVR of 1.5% yields 2,250 conversions versus target of 3,500.

Gap: 1,250 conversions (36% short)

Root cause: Efficiency-driven. Traffic volume is adequate but conversion rate is below vertical median of 2.2%.

OPTIONS:

Option 1: Improve CVR to vertical median
- Target CVR: 2.2%
- Projected conversions: 3,300
- Gap closure: 84%

Option 2: Improve CVR to best-in-class
- Target CVR: 3.0%
- Projected conversions: 4,500
- Exceeds target by 29%

Option 3: Adjust goal to match current efficiency
- Recommended target: 2,500-2,750 conversions
- Represents achievable outcome at current CVR with modest improvement

What would you like to focus on?

2. If gap greater than 10 percent, trigger gap detection
3. Identify root cause (budget, efficiency, channel, market)
4. Present applicable options from the 6 options framework

| Root Cause | Primary Options | Secondary Options |
|------------|-----------------|-------------------|
| Budget-driven | 1 (Budget), 5 (Goal) | 6 (Combine) |
| Efficiency-driven | 2 (CVR), 3 (CTR) | 4 (Channel), 6 (Combine) |
| Channel-driven | 4 (Channel Mix) | 1 (Budget), 6 (Combine) |
| Market-driven | 5 (Goal Adjust) | 6 (Combine) |

Gap Percentage: ((Target - Projection) / Target) x 100
Additional Budget Needed: Gap x Current CPA
Required CVR: Target Conversions / Projected Clicks
Required CTR: Required Clicks / Projected Impressions

When vertical-specific benchmarks are missing:
- Use GENERAL vertical benchmarks as fallback
- Flag uncertainty: These projections use general benchmarks. Your vertical may perform differently.
- Recommend conservative estimates

When no option is viable:
- Acknowledge the constraint clearly
- Present the achievable outcome given constraints
- Offer to revisit if constraints change
- Document the gap for stakeholder communication
sectionTitle: 8.2 IF USER CONSTRAINTS ELIMINATE ALL OPTIONS

content:
When gap is less than 10 percent:
- Do not trigger full gap detection
- Note that projections are close to target
- Suggest margin of error may cover the gap
- Offer optimization suggestions if user wants to close fully

User time is precious. Every question must earn its place by meaningfully improving the plan. If an answer would not change your recommendation, do not ask the question. A plan built on reasonable assumptions is infinitely better than an interrogation that never produces a plan.

Your job is to help users become better marketers. Every interaction should leave them more capable than before.

Before asking any question: Does the user understand WHY this matters? If not, explain the strategic connection first. A question without context is interrogation. A question with context is mentorship.

Target 75 words or fewer per response. Complex scenarios do not justify longer responses.

Signs you are writing too much:
- Response exceeds three short paragraphs

META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: loop_prevention, questions, assumptions
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

A loop occurs when you ask for the same type of information multiple times. Signs:
- User responses become shorter or frustrated
- User repeats information already provided
- You have asked more than two questions about same topic

When you have asked same question type twice without new information:
- Stop asking immediately
- State what you will assume and why
- Cite the source for your assumption
- Move forward

sectionTitle: SECTION 7: WHEN TO CALCULATE VS ASK

content:
- You have minimum viable data for current step
- Additional detail would not change recommendation
- User shows uncertainty and you can use benchmarks
- You have asked same question type twice
- User signals readiness to move on

- Immediately when you have budget and volume target
- When user provides any quantitative data enabling calculation
- When you can make reasonable assumptions from benchmarks

A calculation with a flagged assumption teaches more than another question.

META_INTENT: GENERAL

META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1
When you use an acronym, define it on first use. This ensures clarity for users of all sophistication levels.

- CAC: Customer Acquisition Cost
- ROAS: Return on Ad Spend
- LTV: Lifetime Value
- CPM: Cost per Thousand impressions
- CPA: Cost per Acquisition
- CPC: Cost per Click
- CTR: Click-Through Rate
- CVR: Conversion Rate
- AOV: Average Order Value
- MQL: Marketing Qualified Lead
- SQL: Sales Qualified Lead

CORRECT: Your target CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost) of 50 dollars is realistic.
CORRECT: Based on KB data, typical LTV (Lifetime Value) for ecommerce runs 150 to 300 dollars.
INCORRECT: Your CAC is 50 dollars.

META_SECTION_ID: one_question_rule
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: questions, conversation_flow, single_question
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1
Ask ONE question per response. Wait for the answer before asking another. Multiple questions overwhelm users and slow progress.

The only exception is when listing 2-3 closely related sub-items for a single decision. Even then, frame as one compound question.

CORRECT: What is your budget for this campaign?
CORRECT: For your audience, are we targeting B2B decision-makers or end users, and what industries?
INCORRECT: What is your budget? What about your timeline? Do you have historical data?

META_SECTION_ID: tone_warmth
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: tone, warmth, supportive, collaborative
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
Be warm, supportive, and collaborative. You are a trusted advisor, not an interrogator.

- Start responses with acknowledgment when appropriate
- Use collaborative language: we, together, our plan
- Express confidence in the user's ability to succeed
- Celebrate progress and good decisions

- "Great question - here's how we can approach this..."
- "That budget gives us good flexibility..."
- "With your target of X, we can build a strong plan..."
- "Building on what you've shared..."

- "You need to provide..."
- "I cannot proceed without..."
- "That's not enough information..."
- Cold, transactional phrasing

META_SECTION_ID: sophistication_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 2,3
META_TOPICS: purpose, core_principle
META_INTENT: AUDIENCE_TARGETING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

This document provides guidance on scaling audience definition rigor based on objective type, budget size, and risk profile. It helps determine when to push for more sophistication and when simpler approaches are appropriate.

Audience sophistication should match the precision required by the objective. Brand building with broad reach requires less targeting precision than performance marketing with tight efficiency requirements. Over-targeting can reduce scale. Under-targeting can waste budget.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: sophistication_tiers
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 2,3
META_TOPICS: tier_1, tier_2, tier_3, signal_count
META_INTENT: AUDIENCE_TARGETING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Appropriate for: Brand and upper-funnel objectives

Focus:
- Basic demographic alignment
- Broad interest categories
- Contextual relevance
- Geographic targeting

Use when:
- Objective is awareness or consideration
- Audience is broad by design
- Budget is sufficient for wide reach
- Learning is more valuable than immediate efficiency

Appropriate for: Mid-funnel and consideration objectives

Focus:
- Specific behavioral signals
- Purchase intent indicators
- Category interest
- Life-stage targeting

Use when:
- Objective is consideration or preference
- Audience has identifiable characteristics
- Efficiency matters but not primary constraint
- Some testing budget exists

Appropriate for: Performance and lower-funnel objectives

Focus:
- Strong intent signals
- Recency indicators
- Custom audiences
- Lookalike expansion from high-value customers

Use when:
- Objective is conversion or revenue
- Efficiency targets are tight
- Data is available to support precision
- Measurement can attribute results

Age, gender, income, education, occupation, household composition, life stage.

Foundational but often insufficient alone. Census data provides base population.

Past purchase, browsing history, engagement patterns, content consumption, search behavior.

Generally more predictive than demographics. Google In-Market, Meta Behaviors.

Content adjacency, time of day, device type, location context.

Increasingly important in privacy-constrained environments. IAB Content Taxonomy.

Search queries, comparison behavior, cart abandonment, pricing page visits.

Strongest performance indicators. Limited availability, often expensive.

Values, attitudes, interests, lifestyle, brand affinity.

Useful for message alignment. Meta Interests, Google Affinity.

Required reach = Target conversions / Expected CVR / Reach-to-action ratio

If required reach exceeds addressable audience, either objective or audience must adjust.
All audience size estimates must start with census-validated population data. Agent MUST web search for current census data.

- Very high CPMs from tight targeting

META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE

Measurement exists to inform decisions, not to prove success. The goal is accurate understanding of marketing impact, not favorable reporting. Honest measurement enables optimization. Biased measurement enables waste.

META_SECTION_ID: measurement_trinity
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 8
META_TOPICS: mmm, mta, incrementality, triangulation
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Characteristics:
- Top-down statistical analysis using aggregate data
- Measures all channels including offline
- Accounts for external factors
- Strategic timeframe (quarterly, annually)
- Privacy-safe (no user-level tracking)

Best For: Budget allocation, channel mix optimization, long-term planning

Characteristics:
- Bottom-up analysis using user-level journey data
- Assigns credit to digital touchpoints
- Near real-time optimization
- Tactical timeframe (daily, weekly)
- Requires user-level tracking (privacy challenged)

Best For: In-flight optimization, creative testing, tactical decisions

Characteristics:
- Controlled experiments measuring true causal impact
- Holdout groups establish baseline
- Isolates marketing effect from organic demand
- Gold standard for proving causation

Best For: Validating channel value, major budget decisions, new channel evaluation

No single approach provides complete truth. Triangulate:
- If MMM and MTA agree: High confidence
- If MMM and incrementality agree: Strong strategic evidence
- If MTA and incrementality disagree: Investigate attribution assumptions
- If all three disagree: Examine data quality

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: attribution_models
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 8
META_TOPICS: first_touch, last_touch, multi_touch, data_driven
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

First-Touch Attribution:
- 100% credit to first interaction
- Best for: Awareness channel effectiveness
- Use when: Evaluating top-of-funnel campaigns

Last-Touch Attribution:
- 100% credit to final interaction
- Best for: Immediate conversion triggers
- Use when: Short cycles, direct response, limited data

Linear Attribution:
- Equal credit to all touchpoints
- Simple, fair distribution
- Weakness: Ignores relative impact

Time-Decay Attribution:
- More credit to recent touchpoints
- Better for short consideration cycles
- Weakness: May undervalue awareness

Position-Based (U-Shaped):
- 40% first, 40% last, 20% middle
- Balances awareness and conversion
- Common default for complex funnels

Uses machine learning to determine credit based on actual conversion patterns.
- Requires significant conversion volume (300+/month minimum)
- Most accurate when data is sufficient
- Platform-specific (Google, Meta implementations differ)

META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Client-Side (Pixel-Based):
- Standard implementation
- Subject to ad blockers and ITP
- 20-40% signal loss expected

Server-Side (CAPI):
- Direct server communication
- More reliable in privacy era
- Requires development resources

Hybrid (Recommended):
- Both client and server tracking
- Deduplication required
- Best balance of coverage and reliability

Minimum Standards:
- Conversion pixel firing within 24 hours of conversion
- Revenue values passed accurately
- Unique transaction IDs for deduplication
- Consistent event naming across platforms

This document provides diagnostic reasoning patterns and expert-level guidance for audience strategy decisions. The agent MUST use this document to identify targeting issues, surface audience implications, validate sizing with census data, and produce activation-ready taxonomy codes.

This document covers:
- Critical audience considerations that determine success
- Common pitfalls with recommended alternatives
- Diagnostic signals indicating audience problems
- Audience overlap and segmentation guidance
- Census data validation requirements
- Platform taxonomy code requirements
- Questions worth asking that users may not consider
- Benchmark reference points for audience planning

META_SECTION_ID: audience_critical_considerations
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 2,3,4
META_TOPICS: precision_scale, first_party_data, audience_quality, overlap, census_validation
META_INTENT: AUDIENCE_TARGETING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

CONSIDERATION 1: PRECISION VERSUS SCALE TRADEOFF
Narrow targeting increases relevance but limits reach. Broad targeting increases reach but reduces efficiency. The right balance depends on objectives and budget.

Why it matters: Too narrow wastes budget on high frequency to small audiences. Too broad wastes budget on irrelevant impressions.

CONSIDERATION 2: FIRST-PARTY DATA ADVANTAGE
First-party data enables the most precise and efficient targeting. Lookalike audiences from high-value customers typically outperform prospecting by 40-60 percent.

Why it matters: Advertisers with strong first-party data have significant competitive advantage.

CONSIDERATION 3: AUDIENCE QUALITY OVER QUANTITY
Not all impressions are equal. Reaching the right audience at lower volume beats reaching the wrong audience at high volume.

Why it matters: Poor audience targeting is the most common cause of campaign underperformance.

CONSIDERATION 4: AUDIENCE OVERLAP ACROSS PLATFORMS
Different platforms often reach the same users. Without coordination, audiences receive excessive frequency or redundant targeting.

Why it matters: Unmanaged overlap wastes budget and can cause audience fatigue.

CONSIDERATION 5: AUDIENCE EVOLUTION OVER TIME
Audiences are not static. Customer profiles change, new segments emerge, existing segments shrink or grow.

Why it matters: Audiences that worked historically may not work today.

CONSIDERATION 6: CENSUS-VALIDATED SIZING
Audience size estimates must be grounded in official population data. Guesses and estimates without census validation lead to flawed plans.

Why it matters: Over-estimated audiences lead to under-delivery. Under-estimated audiences lead to over-frequency and waste.

ata. Guesses and estimates without census validation lead to flawed plans.

Why it matters: Over-estimated audiences lead to under-delivery. Under-estimated audiences lead to over-frequency and waste.

CONSIDERATION 7: ACTIVATION-READY OUTPUTS
Audience definitions without platform taxonomy codes require manual translation, introducing errors and delays.

Why it matters: Taxonomy codes enable direct activation in advertising platforms.

META_SECTION_ID: audience_pitfalls
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 2,3
META_TOPICS: pitfalls, demographic_targeting, audience_sizing, suppression, taxonomy
META_INTENT: AUDIENCE_TARGETING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

What it looks like:
- Audience defined only by age, gender, income
- No behavioral or intent signals included
- Assumption that demographics predict behavior

Why it matters:
- Demographics poorly predict purchase behavior
- Large portions of demographic audiences are irrelevant
- Better signals are available on most platforms

Better approach:
- Start with behavioral and intent signals
- Use demographics as secondary refinement
- Include Google In-Market and Meta Behaviors in targeting spec

What it looks like:
- Small audience size with large budget
- Very high frequency delivery
- Rapid creative fatigue

Better approach:
- Match audience size to budget and duration using census data
- Set frequency caps
- Expand audience when frequency exceeds optimal
sectionTitle: 3.2 PITFALL: AUDIENCE TOO NARROW FOR BUDGET

content:
What it looks like:
- Acquisition campaigns reaching existing customers
- Retargeting reaching recent purchasers
- Wasted spend on wrong audience

Better approach:
- Upload customer suppression lists regularly
- Use platform exclusions for recent purchasers
- Monitor new-to-brand rate as quality check

What it looks like:
- Round number estimates like 500K or 1M without methodology
- Platform reach estimates used without population base
- No geographic breakdown of audience sizing

Better approach:
- Always start with census population data
- Apply targeting filters with explicit percentages
- Show calculation chain from population to target audience
- Cite census source and year for all population figures
sectionTitle: 3.4 PITFALL: AUDIENCE SIZE WITHOUT CENSUS VALIDATION

content:
What it looks like:
- Natural language audience description only
- No platform-specific targeting parameters
- Activation team must interpret and translate

Better approach:
- Include IAB codes for contextual targeting
- Include Google Affinity and In-Market codes
- Include Meta Interests and Behaviors
- Include LinkedIn parameters for B2B
- Web search for current taxonomy codes

TIER 1: HIGH-VALUE LOOKALIKES
- Source: Top 10-20 percent customers by LTV
- Typical performance: Best efficiency, limited scale

TIER 2: BROAD LOOKALIKES
- Source: All customers or all converters
- Typical performance: Good efficiency, moderate scale

TIER 3: INTEREST AND BEHAVIOR
- Source: Platform interest and behavior signals
- Typical performance: Moderate efficiency, good scale
- Taxonomy: Google Affinity, Meta Interests

TIER 4: BROAD TARGETING
- Source: Minimal targeting, algorithm-driven
- Typical performance: Variable efficiency, maximum scale

Minimum viable audience sizes by platform:
- Meta: 100,000 minimum for effective optimization
- Google Display: 100,000 minimum
- LinkedIn: 50,000 minimum
- TikTok: 100,000 minimum
- Programmatic: Varies by inventory, typically 100,000 plus

This document provides diagnostic reasoning patterns and expert-level guidance for budget allocation and pacing decisions. The agent MUST use this document to identify issues a novice might miss, surface implications of budget choices, and ask questions that strengthen the media plan.

This document covers:
- Critical budget considerations that determine success

META_SECTION_ID: budget_critical_considerations
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6
META_TOPICS: goal_alignment, channel_sufficiency, funnel_balance, timing, flexibility
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

CONSIDERATION 1: GOAL ALIGNMENT
Budget MUST be mathematically consistent with stated objectives. If the goal is 10,000 customers and budget is 200K, implied CAC is 20 dollars. The agent MUST verify this is realistic for the vertical and channels.

Why it matters: Misaligned budgets create plans that cannot succeed. Either the goal must adjust or the budget must increase.

CONSIDERATION 2: CHANNEL SUFFICIENCY
Each channel needs minimum investment to generate meaningful data and performance. Spreading budget too thin across many channels produces noise, not signal.

Why it matters: Underfunded channels cannot optimize effectively. Better to focus 3 channels well than 6 channels poorly.

CONSIDERATION 3: FUNNEL BALANCE
Budget allocation across funnel stages affects long-term efficiency. Over-investing in lower funnel depletes demand. Over-investing in upper funnel delays results.

Why it matters: The right balance depends on brand maturity, competitive position, and business timeline.

CONSIDERATION 4: TIMING AND PACING
How budget is distributed over time affects learning cycles, competitive positioning, and performance optimization.

Why it matters: Front-loaded budgets generate data faster but risk waste before optimization. Back-loaded budgets optimize better but may miss market timing.

CONSIDERATION 5: FLEXIBILITY RESERVES
Plans SHOULD include contingency for optimization shifts, competitive response, and unexpected opportunities.

Why it matters: Rigid budgets cannot respond to performance signals. Industry practice is 10-15 percent flexibility reserve.

META_SECTION_ID: budget_pitfalls
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 5,6
META_TOPICS: pitfalls, spreading_thin, lower_funnel, minimum_investment
META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

What it looks like:
- Budget divided across 6 or more channels with small allocations
- No channel exceeds minimum investment threshold
- Monthly spend per channel under 2-3K

Why it matters:
- Platforms need minimum spend to optimize algorithms
- Small budgets generate statistically insignificant data
- Team attention is fragmented

Better approach:
- Prioritize 2-4 channels based on objective alignment
- Fund each channel above minimum threshold
- Add channels only after primary channels mature

What it looks like:
- 80 percent or more budget in search, retargeting, retail media
- Little or no upper funnel investment
- Short-term efficiency metrics look strong

Why it matters:
- Lower funnel harvests demand created elsewhere
- Without upper funnel, demand pool depletes over time
- Rising CPAs and declining volume follow

Better approach:
- Allocate minimum 20-30 percent to upper funnel
- Track leading indicators of demand health
- Adjust balance based on business maturity

What it looks like:
- Channels funded below platform minimums
- Campaigns stuck in learning phase indefinitely
- Erratic performance and unreliable data

Better approach:
- Verify minimum thresholds before allocation
- Cut channels that cannot be funded adequately
- Consolidate budget in fewer, well-funded channels

What it looks like:
- 100 percent of budget committed at planning
- No room for optimization shifts
- Cannot respond to performance signals

Better approach:
- Reserve 10-15 percent for optimization
- Release reserve based on performance data
- Build flexibility into channel allocations

What it looks like:
- Heavy spend in early weeks or months
- Budget exhausted before optimization learnings
- Limited ability to apply insights

Better approach:
- Match pacing to learning needs
- Front-load only when timing advantages exist
- Reserve budget for optimization phase

sectionTitle: 4.1 IF BUDGET SEEMS LOW FOR GOALS

content:

- Will additional spend face diminishing returns
- Are there other objectives that could absorb budget

- Have you had issues spending budget efficiently before
- Are there secondary objectives worth pursuing
sectionTitle: 4.2 IF BUDGET SEEMS HIGH FOR GOALS

content:

- Does allocation match funnel objectives
- Are any channels below minimum threshold
- Is mix driven by evidence or habit

Questions to ask:

- Which channels have proven most effective
- Are there channels you want to test but have not funded

What to check:
- Does timing match business events
- Is there a learning period assumption
- What happens if budget runs out early

Questions to ask:

- How quickly do you typically see performance stabilize
- What is the cost of missing timing versus overspending early
sectionTitle: 4.4 IF PACING SEEMS AGGRESSIVE OR CONSERVATIVE

content:
What to check:
- Use vertical benchmarks for projections
- Flag higher uncertainty in estimates
- Build in more testing allocation

Approach:
- Start with conservative estimates
- Set expectations for learning phase
- Plan for optimization adjustments

META_SECTION_ID: budget_benchmarks

META_TOPICS: benchmarks, minimums, funnel_allocation, pacing
META_INTENT: BENCHMARK_LOOKUP, BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Monthly minimums for meaningful performance:
- Google Search: 5K-10K minimum
- Meta (Facebook/Instagram): 5K-10K minimum
- Programmatic Display: 10K-15K minimum
- CTV/OTT: 15K-25K minimum
- LinkedIn: 5K-10K minimum
- TikTok: 5K-10K minimum
- Retail Media: Varies by platform, typically 10K minimum

Note: These are general guidelines. Actual minimums depend on vertical, geography, and targeting.

By business maturity:
- New brand: 60-70 percent upper funnel, 30-40 percent lower funnel
- Growing brand: 40-50 percent upper funnel, 50-60 percent lower funnel
- Mature brand: 20-30 percent upper funnel, 70-80 percent lower funnel

By objective:
- Awareness focus: 60-80 percent upper funnel
- Consideration focus: 40-60 percent mid funnel
- Conversion focus: 60-80 percent lower funnel
- Balanced: 30-30-40 across funnel stages

Standard pacing patterns:
- Even pacing: Equal spend across periods (default)
- Front-loaded: 40-50 percent in first half (for time-sensitive objectives)
- Back-loaded: 40-50 percent in second half (for optimization-dependent objectives)
- Seasonal: Matched to business patterns (for retail, travel, etc.)

Industry practice:
- Minimum: 5 percent flexibility reserve
- Standard: 10-15 percent flexibility reserve
- Aggressive optimization: 20 percent flexibility reserve

This document provides diagnostic reasoning patterns and expert-level guidance for channel mix decisions. The agent MUST use this document to identify issues a novice might miss, surface channel interdependencies, and ask questions that strengthen the media plan.

This document covers:
- Critical channel considerations that determine success
- Common pitfalls with recommended alternatives
