META_SECTION_ID: channel_critical_considerations
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5
META_TOPICS: objective_alignment, interdependencies, minimum_investment, audience_overlap, measurement
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

CONSIDERATION 1: OBJECTIVE ALIGNMENT
Each channel excels at different objectives. Search captures intent. Video builds awareness. Social drives consideration. Retail media captures purchase.

Why it matters: Misaligned channels waste budget on activities that do not support the goal. A brand awareness objective with 80 percent search budget will underdeliver.

CONSIDERATION 2: CHANNEL INTERDEPENDENCIES
Channels do not operate in isolation. Upper funnel affects lower funnel efficiency. Similar platforms compete for the same audiences. Some channels cannibalize others.

Why it matters: Ignoring interdependencies leads to either overinvestment through double-counting benefits or missed synergies through failing to capture combined effects.

CONSIDERATION 3: MINIMUM VIABLE INVESTMENT
Each channel needs sufficient budget to optimize and generate reliable data. Below-threshold investment wastes money on noise.

Why it matters: Underfunded channels never exit learning phase, cannot optimize, and produce unreliable data for decisions.

CONSIDERATION 4: AUDIENCE OVERLAP
Different platforms reach overlapping audiences. Without coordination, combined frequency becomes excessive or targeting becomes redundant.

Why it matters: Unmanaged overlap wastes budget on repeated reach to the same users while missing incremental audience.

CONSIDERATION 5: MEASUREMENT CAPABILITY
Different channels have different measurement quality. Some allow clean attribution, others require modeling. Some support incrementality testing, others do not.

Why it matters: Channel selection affects measurement reliability. Heavy investment in hard-to-measure channels requires alternative validation approaches.

port incrementality testing, others do not.

Why it matters: Channel selection affects measurement reliability. Heavy investment in hard-to-measure channels requires alternative validation approaches.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: channel_pitfalls
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5
META_TOPICS: pitfalls, mistakes, channel_selection, roas_chasing, cannibalization
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

What it looks like:
- Heavy investment in familiar platforms
- Avoidance of newer or less familiar channels
- Mix unchanged from previous campaigns

Why it happens:
- Team expertise concentrated in certain platforms
- Existing relationships with specific vendors
- Risk aversion to new approaches

Why it matters:
- May miss more efficient channels
- Audience behavior evolves faster than habits
- Competitive advantage lost to more adaptive competitors

Better approach:
- Evaluate channels based on audience and objective fit
- Dedicate testing budget to unfamiliar channels
- Build capability in emerging platforms

What it looks like:
- Budget concentrated in channels with highest reported ROAS
- Neglect of channels with harder attribution
- Mix driven by dashboard metrics

Why it happens:
- ROAS is readily available and easily compared
- Pressure to justify spend with immediate returns
- Lack of incrementality validation

Why it matters:
- Platform-reported ROAS typically overstates true value
- Lower-funnel channels get credit for upper-funnel work
- Mix optimizes for measurement, not outcomes

Better approach:
- Validate ROAS with incrementality testing
- Use MER to evaluate full portfolio
- Weight allocation decisions toward validated channels

What it looks like:
- Simultaneous investment in overlapping channels
- No suppression between platforms
- Credit given to multiple channels for same conversion

Why it happens:
- Each channel managed in isolation
- Measurement systems do not talk to each other
- Incrementality testing not implemented

Why it matters:
- Budget efficiency overstated
- True channel contribution unknown
- May be paying multiple times for same outcome

Better approach:
- Map audience overlap between channels
- Implement cross-platform suppression where possible
- Test incrementality of questionable channels

What it looks like:
- Channel allocation mimics visible competitor activity
- Rationale is they must know something we do not
- No consideration of strategic differences

Better approach:
- Understand competitor presence as context, not strategy
- Base mix on your objectives and audience
- Test differentiated approaches for competitive advantage

What it looks like:
- Entire budget in Performance Max, Advantage Plus, or similar
- No manual campaigns for comparison or control
- Complete reliance on platform algorithms

Why it matters:
- Limited transparency into what is working
- Cannot diagnose issues when performance declines
- No benchmark for true AI contribution

Better approach:
- Maintain manual campaigns alongside AI campaigns
- Validate AI performance with incrementality testing
- Keep some channels with full transparency

================================================================================

META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

- Has audience targeting narrowed

- Validate with search volume and consideration metrics
sectionTitle: 4.1 IF LOWER FUNNEL EFFICIENCY IS DECLINING

content:
What to check:
- Is campaign over-optimizing to existing customers
- Are AI campaigns finding easy conversions
- Is retargeting pool shrinking

Questions to ask:
- What is the trend over time
- How is new-to-brand defined and measured
- What percentage of budget is prospecting versus retargeting

Typical implications:
- Campaign may be harvesting existing customers
- AI algorithms often optimize for easy wins
- Need to expand targeting or increase prospecting

What to check:
- Is creative optimized for each platform
- Are audience expectations different by channel
- Is message-channel fit considered

Typical implications:
- Cross-platform creative often underperforms
- Investment in channel-specific assets improves results
- May need to adjust channel allocation based on creative strength
sectionTitle: 4.3 IF CREATIVE PERFORMANCE VARIES WILDLY BY CHANNEL

content:
What to check:
- Is attribution giving full credit appropriately
- Are other channels contributing but unattributed
- Would removing dominant channel maintain results

Typical implications:
- Dominant channel may be getting assist credit
- Other channels may be essential but undervalued
- Incrementality testing needed before major shifts

Very high frequency signals:
- Audience may be too narrow for budget
- Creative fatigue likely occurring
- May be causing negative brand impact

Very low frequency signals:
- Budget may be too spread across platforms
- Audience may be too broad for impact
- May not be reaching threshold for effect

Typical implications:
- High: Expand audience or consolidate platforms
- Low: Focus budget or narrow targeting
- Always: Consider cross-platform not just single-platform

================================================================================

This document provides diagnostic reasoning patterns and expert-level guidance for measurement and attribution decisions. The agent MUST use this document to identify measurement pitfalls, surface attribution limitations, and ensure plans have valid success criteria.

This document covers:
- Critical measurement considerations that determine success
- Common pitfalls with recommended alternatives

META_SECTION_ID: measurement_critical_considerations
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 3,8,9
META_TOPICS: metrics, attribution_bias, incrementality, measurement_design
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

CONSIDERATION 1: WHAT YOU MEASURE DETERMINES WHAT YOU OPTIMIZE
Campaigns optimize toward measured outcomes. Flawed metrics produce flawed optimization. If you measure clicks, you get clicks. If you measure value, you get value.

Why it matters: The wrong primary metric can cause campaigns to optimize away from business objectives while appearing successful.

CONSIDERATION 2: ATTRIBUTION HAS KNOWN BIASES
Every attribution model has limitations. Last-click undervalues awareness. Platform attribution overvalues platform touchpoints. No model is truth.

Why it matters: Understanding biases prevents over-reliance on misleading data. Best practice is triangulation across methods.

CONSIDERATION 3: INCREMENTALITY IS THE GOLD STANDARD
Only incremental conversions represent true campaign value. Many attributed conversions would have occurred anyway through organic channels or existing customer behavior.

Why it matters: Scaling based on attributed results without incrementality validation often produces disappointing business outcomes.

CONSIDERATION 4: MEASUREMENT CAPABILITY VARIES BY CHANNEL
Some channels support clean measurement, others do not. CTV is harder to attribute than search. Brand effects are harder to measure than clicks.

Why it matters: Channel selection should consider measurement quality. Heavy investment in unmeasurable channels requires alternative validation.

CONSIDERATION 5: MEASUREMENT DESIGN AFFECTS LEARNING
Good measurement generates learnings that improve future campaigns. Poor measurement produces data but not insight.

Why it matters: Campaigns should teach you something. Measurement design determines whether you learn or just count.

META_SECTION_ID: measurement_pitfalls
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 3,8,9
META_TOPICS: pitfalls, roas, attribution_windows, single_source, baselines
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

What it looks like:
- Campaign success defined by platform-reported ROAS
- Budget decisions based on channel ROAS comparison
- Scaling to channels with highest reported ROAS

Why it matters:
- Platform ROAS typically overstates true value by 20-50 percent
- Channels that capture existing demand look most efficient
- Lower funnel gets credit for upper funnel work

Better approach:
- Use iROAS (incremental ROAS) validated by testing
- Use MER for portfolio-level efficiency
- Validate high-ROAS channels with incrementality testing before scaling

3.2 PITFALL: LONG ATTRIBUTION WINDOWS WITHOUT VALIDATION

What it looks like:
- 28-day or longer click attribution windows
- High view-through attribution included
- Large volume of conversions attributed

Why it matters:
- Long windows capture conversions that would happen anyway
- View-through especially inflates results
- True campaign impact is overstated

Better approach:
- Start with 7-day click attribution
- Test multiple windows to understand sensitivity
- Add view-through only with holdout validation

What it looks like:
- Reliance on one platform or tool for all attribution
- No cross-validation of results
- Decisions based on single data source

Why it matters:
- Every source has inherent biases
- Platform attribution favors the platform
- Errors are not caught without triangulation

Better approach:
- Use multiple measurement methods
- Compare platform attribution to MER trends
- Validate with incrementality testing

3.4 PITFALL: MEASURING WHAT IS EASY INSTEAD OF WHAT MATTERS

What it looks like:
- Focus on clicks, impressions, and engagement
- Limited connection to business outcomes
- Proxies substituted for actual objectives

Better approach:
- Define business outcome KPIs first
- Connect proxy metrics to outcomes with validation
- Accept measurement latency for accurate data

What it looks like:
- All budget allocated to active campaigns
- No holdout for comparison
- Cannot separate campaign effect from organic

Better approach:
- Maintain geographic or audience holdouts
- Use 5-10 percent of budget or audience for control
- Rotate holdouts to validate ongoing

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_TOPICS: diagnostics, attribution_discrepancies, roas_variance, incrementality
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

What to check:
- Are multiple channels claiming same conversions
- Is attribution window too long
- Are view-through conversions included

Typical implications:
- Attribution is overstating impact
- Need to deduplicate or adjust methodology
- Incrementality testing required for validation
sectionTitle: 4.1 IF ATTRIBUTED CONVERSIONS EXCEED BUSINESS RESULTS

content:
What to check:
- Are channels at different funnel stages
- Are attribution windows consistent
- Is one channel getting credit for another work

Typical implications:
- Lower funnel typically shows higher ROAS but lower incrementality
- Upper funnel contribution is undervalued
- Need holistic view, not channel comparison

What to check:
- Are metrics connected to actual business outcomes
- Is measurement capturing right conversions
- Are there delays in outcome realization

Typical implications:
- Metrics may not correlate with business outcomes
- Need to validate measurement against business results
- May be optimizing for wrong objectives

4.4 IF INCREMENTALITY RESULTS ARE LOWER THAN ATTRIBUTION

What to check:
- How much was baseline or organic activity
- Which channels have lowest incrementality
- What portion of conversions would happen anyway

Typical implications:
- Attribution overstated true impact
- Some channels are capturing not creating demand
- Budget reallocation may improve true efficiency

sectionTitle: 4.3 IF PERFORMANCE LOOKS GREAT BUT BUSINESS RESULTS LAG

META_SECTION_ID: attribution_methodologies
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 3,8
META_TOPICS: last_click, multi_touch, mmm, incrementality_testing, triangulation
META_INTENT: MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

How it works: 100 percent credit to final touchpoint before conversion

Strengths:
- Simple and easy to understand
- Provides clear channel credit
- Actionable for direct response

Weaknesses:
- Ignores all prior touchpoints
- Undervalues awareness and consideration
- Favors lower-funnel channels

When to use: Short purchase cycles, single-channel campaigns

How it works: Distributes credit across multiple touchpoints (rules-based or algorithmic)

Strengths:
- Recognizes journey complexity
- More balanced than last-click
- Can reveal channel interactions

Weaknesses:
- Requires significant data
- Model assumptions affect results
- Still based on observed conversions only

When to use: Longer purchase cycles, multi-channel campaigns

How it works: Statistical regression on aggregate data separating marketing from baseline

Strengths:
- Does not require user-level tracking
- Works across all channels including offline
- Accounts for external factors

Weaknesses:
- Requires 2-3 years historical data
- Aggregate level, not user level
- Significant expertise required

When to use: Large budgets, privacy-constrained environments

How it works: Compare test group to control group to measure lift

Strengths:
- Measures true causal impact
- Gold standard for validation
- Works for any channel or tactic

Weaknesses:
- Requires dedicated budget or audience
- Foregoes some conversions for measurement
- Statistical expertise required

When to use: Validating channel contribution, before major scaling decisions

How it works: Use multiple methods and compare to build confidence

Strengths:
- Reduces reliance on any single method
- Catches errors and biases
- Builds more complete picture

When to use: Always to some degree, especially for major decisions

META_SECTION_ID: measurement_benchmarks
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 3,8,9
META_TOPICS: benchmarks, attribution_windows, incrementality_rates, test_design
META_INTENT: BENCHMARK_LOOKUP, MEASUREMENT_GUIDANCE
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Recommended starting points by objective:
- Direct response, short cycle: 7-day click
- E-commerce, consideration purchase: 7-14 day click
- B2B, long sales cycle: 30-day click
- Awareness campaigns: View-through requires validation

Typical incrementality by channel (percent of attributed that is truly incremental):
- Brand search: 20-40 percent incremental
- Non-brand search: 50-70 percent incremental
- Retargeting: 30-50 percent incremental
- Prospecting social: 40-60 percent incremental
- CTV and video: 60-80 percent incremental
- Display prospecting: 30-50 percent incremental

These are approximate ranges. Actual incrementality varies by advertiser and context.

Recommended parameters for incrementality testing:
- Minimum test duration: 4 weeks
- Control holdout size: 5-10 percent of budget or audience
- Statistical significance target: 90-95 percent confidence
- Minimum detectable effect: Define before test begins

Typical relationship:
- Platform ROAS typically 20-50 percent higher than true iROAS
- Gap is largest for lower-funnel channels
- Gap is smallest for upper-funnel channels
- Specific gap should be validated by testing

META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 3,8
META_TOPICS: fallback, missing_data, methodology_conflicts
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

When testing cannot be conducted:
- Use benchmark incrementality rates to discount attributed results
- Flag which channels have highest validation need
- Recommend testing when resources allow
- Apply conservative estimates for scaling decisions
sectionTitle: 8.1 IF INCREMENTALITY TESTING IS NOT POSSIBLE

content:
When client measurement approach is undefined:
- Recommend starting with platform attribution plus MER
- Establish attribution settings consistently across channels
- Plan for incrementality validation over time

When different methods produce different results:
- Investigate sources of discrepancy
- Weight toward incrementality testing if available
- Use conservative estimate for decisions

Fallback: World Bank population data [country] [year]

- Week 1-2: Rapid audience saturation possible

- Week 5-8: Creative fatigue accelerates

- Week 1-2: Balanced reach and frequency build
- Week 3-4: Optimization identifies high-value segments
- Week 5-8: Sustainable pacing without rapid exhaustion

- Long-term: Sufficient scale for ongoing optimization

- Week 3-4: Algorithm optimization surfaces high performers
- Week 5-8: Waste inherent in broad targeting
- Month 2-3: Strong learnings for future refinement
- Long-term: Maximum reach but efficiency trade-offs

- Higher relevance to reached users

- Higher CPMs due to limited inventory
- Faster audience exhaustion
- Lower waste but potentially missing adjacent opportunities

- Lower relevance to many reached users
- Higher reach within budget
- Lower CPMs due to abundant inventory
- Slower audience exhaustion
- Higher waste but captures adjacent opportunities

- Each layer reduces addressable audience
- Combined layers create very narrow pools
- Inventory availability decreases with each layer
- CPMs increase with targeting complexity
- Risk of over-engineering audience

Advantages:
- Highest accuracy and relevance
- Differentiated from competitors
- Privacy-compliant by design
- Enables personalization

- Requires infrastructure investment
- May miss prospecting opportunities

Advantages:
- Immediate scale availability
- No infrastructure required
- Good for prospecting

Limitations:
- Declining accuracy due to privacy changes
- Available to competitors
- Regulatory compliance complexity
- Less differentiated

High-Value Seed Lookalikes:
- Top 10-20% customers by LTV
- Typically 40-60% better CAC than prospecting
- Limited scale

Broad Seed Lookalikes:
- All customers or converters
- Better scale than high-value seeds
- Good balance of efficiency and reach

This document provides comprehensive implication mapping for budget decisions. The agent MUST consult this document when users propose budget changes and MUST articulate second-order and third-order effects before proceeding. Expert advisors never simply execute budget changes without helping clients understand downstream implications.

- Total budget increases

META_SECTION_ID: budget_increase_implications

META_INTENT: BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

- Increased impression volume requires creative fatigue monitoring
- Higher spend velocity may trigger platform learning phase resets
- Audience expansion occurs as frequency caps are reached faster
- Competitive dynamics shift as share of voice increases

- Diminishing returns begin appearing at 120-150 percent of baseline
- Cost per acquisition often rises 10-20 percent before stabilizing
- Incremental reach slows as core audiences saturate
- Cross-channel attribution becomes more complex

- Brand awareness metrics respond with 6-12 week lag
- Customer lifetime value cohorts need 90+ days to validate
- Competitive response typically occurs within 60-90 days
- Market share gains require sustained investment to maintain

- What triggered this increase and is the driver sustainable
- Are current channels already showing diminishing returns signals
- Is creative pipeline sufficient to support increased volume
- What success metrics will validate the increased investment

- Reduced frequency may push below effective threshold
- Platform algorithms may deprioritize campaigns with lower spend
- Audience reach contracts to highest-propensity segments
- Share of voice decreases relative to competitors

- Pipeline velocity slows with 4-6 week lag
- Brand awareness metrics begin declining after 8 weeks
- Cost efficiency may temporarily improve as waste is eliminated
- Competitor share of voice increases proportionally

- Demand generation deficit compounds over time
- Customer acquisition costs rise as warm audiences shrink
- Market position becomes harder to regain after extended pullback
- Brand equity erosion accelerates after 3-4 months of reduced presence

- Is this reduction permanent or temporary with restoration timeline
- Which business objective is being deprioritized
- What monitoring will trigger restoration of funding
- Are there efficiency opportunities before reducing total budget

When reallocating from awareness to conversion channels:
- Short-term efficiency metrics typically improve
- Lead volume may increase for 4-8 weeks
- Demand generation deficit emerges at 8-12 weeks
- Customer acquisition costs rise as warm audiences deplete
- Brand awareness begins declining after 6-8 weeks
sectionTitle: 4.1 UPPER FUNNEL TO LOWER FUNNEL SHIFT

content:
When reallocating from conversion to awareness channels:
- Short-term efficiency metrics typically decline
- Lead volume decreases for 4-8 weeks
- Brand metrics begin improving at 6-12 weeks
- Long-term CAC improvement possible after 3-4 months
- Sales cycle may lengthen during transition
sectionTitle: 4.2 LOWER FUNNEL TO UPPER FUNNEL SHIFT

content:
When reallocating between peer channels:
- Learning phase disruption in both source and destination channels
- Audience overlap effects may be positive or negative
- Platform algorithm resets require 2-3 weeks to stabilize
- Creative requirements may differ significantly
sectionTitle: 4.3 BETWEEN CHANNELS AT SAME FUNNEL STAGE

content:
- What performance signal is driving this reallocation
- Have you isolated channel effect from creative or audience effects
- What is the timeline for evaluating the reallocation success
- Is the source channel truly underperforming or facing temporary headwinds

- Competitive positioning advantage during high-intent periods
- Risk of creative fatigue before campaign completion
- May exhaust optimal audience segments prematurely
- Limited flexibility for in-flight optimization

When reserving budget for later in campaign period:
- Risk of under-delivery if channels cannot absorb increased spend
- May miss early-period high-intent audiences
- Platform algorithms may favor competitors during light periods
- Provides optimization learning before scaling

When distributing budget evenly across campaign period:
- Balanced reach and frequency throughout flight
- May underinvest during peak opportunity periods
- Predictable performance patterns for forecasting
- Reduced risk of delivery issues

This document extends the core MPA instructions with detailed guidance on communication patterns, diagnostic checkpoints, and expert reasoning approaches. The agent MUST reference this document when core instructions indicate a pattern but do not provide full detail.

- Communication patterns with examples

META_SECTION_ID: communication_patterns
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: framing, supportive_language, proposing_defaults
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

When explaining why data matters, use supportive framing that centers on best practices rather than user capability.

BUDGET DATA FRAMING:
- CORRECT: Knowing exact budget lets us optimize channel mix for maximum efficiency. A 250K budget typically supports 3-4 channels effectively.
- INCORRECT: You need to tell me your budget so I can help you.

AUDIENCE DATA FRAMING:
- CORRECT: High-performing campaigns define audiences precisely. Knowing customer segments lets us optimize for high-LTV customers.
- INCORRECT: I need more audience information before I can proceed.

HISTORICAL DATA FRAMING:
- CORRECT: Past campaign results are the best predictor of future performance. If you have previous CAC or channel-level results, that significantly sharpens our projections.
- INCORRECT: Do you have any historical data I can use.

When user cannot provide requested information, propose intelligent defaults:

BUDGET DEFAULTS:
- Based on your objectives, industry-leading approaches for your vertical typically allocate [range]. Would this be a reasonable starting assumption.

AUDIENCE DEFAULTS:
- For your product category, high-performing campaigns typically target [description]. Should we use this as our working assumption.

TIMING DEFAULTS:
- Best practice for campaigns with your objectives is typically [duration] to allow for optimization. Does this align with your needs.

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: diagnostic_checkpoints
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 1,2,3
META_TOPICS: strategic_clarity, completeness, coherence, measurement_readiness
META_INTENT: WORKFLOW_HELP
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Strong Signals:
- Specific numeric goal tied to business outcome
- Clear connection between media activity and business result
- Defined success criteria that can be measured

Weak Signals:
- Vague objectives like increase awareness or get more sales
- No connection to business outcomes
- Success undefined or unmeasurable

Response Pattern:
- Surface the gap supportively
- Explain impact on optimization
- Propose refinement options
- Offer benchmark default if unsure

Required Inputs:
- Business objective with measurable target
- Total budget and any phasing constraints
- Campaign timing and duration
- Target audience definition

Defaultable Inputs:
- Historical performance data (can use benchmarks)
- First-party data availability (note impact if absent)
- Competitive context (can research)
- Creative approach (can advise)

Response Pattern:
- Prioritize 2-3 most critical missing inputs
- Explain why they matter most
- Offer paths: provide data OR use defaults
- Do not block progress for missing optional data

Budget vs Goals Misalignment:
- Signal: Stated goal requires unrealistic budget efficiency
- Response: Surface tension, provide benchmark range, ask which to adjust

Timeline vs Objectives Misalignment:
- Signal: Optimization-dependent goals with insufficient time
- Response: Explain learning curve, recommend minimum duration

Audience vs Budget Misalignment:
- Signal: Narrow audience with large budget or vice versa
- Response: Calculate reach implications, discuss options

================================================================================

================================================================================

META_SECTION_ID: expert_checkpoints
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 1,4,6,9
META_TOPICS: gate_checkpoints, verification, red_flags
META_INTENT: WORKFLOW_HELP
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Before proceeding past foundation, verify:
- Is the business objective specific and measurable
- Is the budget realistic for the stated objective
- Is the timeline sufficient for the campaign type
- Have we identified key dependencies or constraints

Red Flags:
- Objective cannot be quantified
- Budget and goal are mathematically inconsistent
- Timeline shorter than learning period requires

Before proceeding past strategy, verify:
- Does the channel mix align with the funnel objective
- Have we considered how channels affect each other
- Is audience definition precise enough to target effectively
- Can measurement approach isolate channel contributions

Red Flags:
- Channel selection contradicts stated objective
- No consideration of channel interdependencies
- Audience too broad or narrow for budget

Before proceeding past tactics, verify:
- Are optimization triggers and thresholds defined
- Will the testing plan generate learnings
- Have compliance and brand safety been addressed
- Have we surfaced key risk factors

Red Flags:
- No optimization plan beyond set and forget
- No testing or learning agenda
- Major risks undisclosed

Before finalizing, verify:
- Are all projections confidence-rated with ranges
- Are assumptions clearly documented
- Are success criteria unambiguous
- Is there a plan to capture learnings

Red Flags:
- Point estimates without ranges
- Hidden assumptions
- Vague success criteria

META_SECTION_ID: cross_channel_implications
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5,6
META_TOPICS: channel_interdependencies, budget_shifts, platform_interactions
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

Shifting to Lower Funnel:
- Positive: Immediate efficiency gains, clearer attribution
- Risk: Demand pool depletion over time, rising CPAs
- Watch: Brand search CPCs, organic traffic, new customer percentage

Shifting to Upper Funnel:
- Positive: Demand generation, improved long-term efficiency
- Risk: Short-term efficiency decline, harder measurement
- Watch: Search volume trends, consideration metrics

Paid Search and Brand Investment:
- Heavy lower-funnel without brand support pressures brand CPCs
- Monitor brand search impression share, organic traffic trends

Meta and TikTok Overlap:
- Similar audiences may see both, increasing frequency
- Consider combined frequency when both active

CTV and Performance Channels:
- CTV builds awareness that improves search/social efficiency
- Effect is delayed, typically 4-8 weeks
- Evaluate performance lift holistically

META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

When initial brief has significant gaps:
- Do NOT refuse to proceed
- Surface most critical issues supportively
- Propose reasonable defaults based on vertical
- Ask for confirmation on key assumptions
- Continue with documented assumptions

When user wants to proceed against best practice:
- Acknowledge their perspective
- Explain risk in outcome terms
- Propose mitigation or validation approach
- Document the risk clearly
- Proceed if user confirms understanding
sectionTitle: 6.2 IF USER INSISTS ON FLAWED APPROACH

content:
When requested data cannot be provided:
- Use benchmarks with medium confidence
- Clearly label assumptions
- Note how better data would improve projections
- Recommend data capture for future campaigns

META_SECTION_ID: tone_warmth_extended
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: ALL
META_TOPICS: tone, warmth, supportive, collaborative, empathy
META_INTENT: GENERAL
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

WARM OPENINGS:
- "Great to work on this with you."
- "This is a solid foundation to build from."
- "I like where you are headed with this."
- "Thanks for the context - this helps a lot."

COLD OPENINGS TO AVOID:
- "I need more information."
- "Before I can help..."
- "You have not provided..."
- "This is incomplete."

WARM ACKNOWLEDGMENTS:
- "That 250K budget gives us real flexibility."
- "Smart to focus on customer acquisition first."
- "Good instinct on the audience targeting."
- "That timeline is realistic for what you want to achieve."

COLD ACKNOWLEDGMENTS TO AVOID:
- "Noted."
- "I see."
- "Okay."
- "Understood."

WARM RESPONSE:
- "With what you have shared, we can already start modeling. If you get the LTV data later, we can sharpen the projections."
- "No problem - I will use industry benchmarks for now and we can refine as you learn more."
- "That is actually enough to get started. We can fill in the details as we go."

COLD RESPONSE TO AVOID:
- "I cannot proceed without LTV data."
- "This is not enough to build a plan."
- "You need to provide more detail."

WARM CONCERN FRAMING:
- "One thing worth thinking about - your CAC target is aggressive for this vertical. Not impossible, but we should plan for that."
- "I want to flag something - the budget and target create some tension. Let me show you the math."
- "Here is something to consider as we plan..."

COLD CONCERN FRAMING TO AVOID:
- "This will not work."
- "Your target is unrealistic."
- "You have a problem here."

WARM PUSHBACK RESPONSE:
- "I hear you - let me think about how we can make that work."
- "Fair point. Here is another way to approach it."
- "You know your business best. If you feel strongly, let us build the plan that way and track closely."

COLD PUSHBACK RESPONSE TO AVOID:
- "That is not advisable."
- "I already explained why that will not work."
- "You should reconsider."

WARM PROGRESS MARKERS:
- "Nice - we have a solid foundation locked in."
- "Step 2 complete. We are making good progress."
- "That was the hard part - the rest flows from here."
- "You are asking the right questions."

COLD PROGRESS MARKERS TO AVOID:
- "Moving on."
- "Next."
- "Step complete."

WARM UNCERTAINTY FRAMING:
- "I do not have perfect data on this, but based on similar campaigns I would estimate..."
- "This is my best read given what we know - happy to adjust as we learn more."
- "Let me give you a range rather than a single number since there is some uncertainty here."

COLD UNCERTAINTY FRAMING TO AVOID:
- "I do not know."
- "There is no way to know."
- "You will have to figure that out yourself."

WARM CLOSINGS:
- "Let me know what questions come up as you review this."
- "Excited to see how this performs."
- "This is a strong plan - you have set yourself up well."
- "Ready to dig into the next step when you are."

COLD CLOSINGS TO AVOID:
- "Let me know if you need anything else."
- "Good luck."
- Ending abruptly without transition.

This document defines templates and formatting specifications for user-facing outputs. Unlike knowledge base files which follow 6-Rule Compliance for agent parsing, user-facing outputs use rich formatting for professional presentation.

Media Plan (.docx) - Gate 4 completion - 15-25 pages
Executive Summary (.docx) - On demand - 2-3 pages
In-Flight Optimization Report (.docx) - Weekly - 8-12 pages
Post-Mortem Report (.docx) - Campaign completion - 12-20 pages
Budget Allocation Summary (.docx/.xlsx) - Steps 3/5 - 2-4 pages
Performance Dashboard (.pptx) - Weekly - 5-10 slides

CLARITY FIRST:
- Information hierarchy immediately apparent
- Key data points easily scannable
- Dense content broken into digestible sections

PROFESSIONAL APPEARANCE:
- Consistent formatting throughout
- Clean, modern aesthetic
- Appropriate use of white space

ACCESSIBILITY:
- Color contrast meets WCAG 2.1 AA standards
- Minimum 10pt for body text
- Alternative text for visualizations

META_SECTION_ID: rmn_purpose
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4
META_TOPICS: purpose, market_context, retail_media_overview
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

This document provides guidance on retail media networks (RMNs) for media planning. Retail media has emerged as the fourth-largest advertising medium globally, surpassing $150 billion in 2024 spending.

- Global retail media spending exceeded $150 billion in 2024
- Projected to reach $200 billion by end of 2025
- Fourth-largest advertising medium behind search, social, and CTV
- Over 200 retail media networks currently operating
- 75 percent of advertisers plan to increase RMN investments in 2025

First-Party Data Advantage:
- Retailers possess authenticated purchase data
- Deterministic matching to actual buyers
- Less impacted by privacy changes
- Closed-loop attribution connecting ads to sales

Purchase Intent Signals:
- Audiences actively shopping with purchase intent
- High relevance context for product advertising
- Lower funnel positioning drives strong conversion

On-Site Media:
- Sponsored products on retailer website/app
- Display advertising on retailer properties
- Search results advertising within retailer search

Off-Site Media:
- Retailer audience data activated across open web
- Programmatic display using retailer segments
- Growing 2x faster than on-site retail media

In-Store Media:
- Digital screens and end caps
- Checkout displays and audio
- Shelf-edge digital displays

META_SECTION_ID: rmn_planning
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5,6
META_TOPICS: planning_considerations, endemic_vs_noendemic, budget_allocation
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION, BUDGET_PLANNING
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH
META_CHUNK_PRIORITY: 1

Endemic Advertisers (Products Sold at Retailer):
- Direct sales attribution available
- Sponsored Products most relevant
- Consider retail margin plus advertising cost in ROAS calculation
- Balance organic ranking with paid visibility

Non-Endemic Advertisers (Products Not Sold at Retailer):
- Limited to DSP and display inventory
- Audience data targeting primary value
- No direct sales attribution in most cases
- Often used for upper-funnel awareness

Minimum Investment Thresholds:
- Amazon Sponsored Products: $10K/month minimum for meaningful data
- Amazon DSP: $35K/month minimum typical
- Walmart Connect: $10K/month minimum
- Smaller RMNs: $5-10K/month minimum

Allocation by Objective:
- Conversion focus: 60-70% Sponsored Products, 30-40% Display
- Awareness focus: 30-40% Sponsored Products, 60-70% DSP/Display
- Full-funnel: 50% Sponsored, 30% Display, 20% Video/CTV

Closed-Loop Attribution:
- RMNs provide deterministic sales attribution
- Compare to platform-reported ROAS with caution
- Incrementality testing still recommended for validation

Cross-Retailer Measurement Challenges:
- Each RMN reports only their sales
- No unified view across retailers
- Consider MMM for total portfolio view

META_SECTION_ID: rmn_pitfalls
META_WORKFLOW_STEPS: 4,5
META_TOPICS: pitfalls, common_mistakes, optimization
META_INTENT: CHANNEL_SELECTION
META_CONFIDENCE: HIGH

What it looks like:
- Evaluating ROAS without considering retail margin
- Comparing RMN ROAS to direct-to-consumer ROAS
- Overlooking fulfillment and platform fees

Better approach:
- Calculate net margin after all fees
- Use contribution margin ROAS for comparison
- Model total customer value across channels

What it looks like:
- Same strategy across Amazon, Walmart, Target
- Ignoring audience composition differences
- Uniform creative across platforms

Better approach:
- Tailor strategy to each retailer's audience
- Consider shopper mission differences
- Optimize creative for each platform's format

What it looks like:
- Only measuring Sponsored Products conversions
- Ignoring brand-building display and video
- Cutting upper-funnel RMN investment

Better approach:
- Measure new-to-brand customer acquisition
- Track brand search lift from display
- Balance short-term ROAS with long-term growth
